message: ] and there seems to be a fair few corpus based talks, nice. There is even a dedicated forum on corpus in the classroom. I have pulled those talks based on searching for the words
Making trouble-free corpus tasks in ten minutes

For business English learners who repeatedly misuse specific vocabulary and grammar, using a corpus (electronic multi-million word collections of real-world language examples) significantly enhances accuracy and competence. Accessible to everyone, with masses of free material to exploit, workshop participants will
leave knowing how to quickly and easily use corpora to design activities that take less than ten minutes to create.
Using corpora to remedy language errors in L2 writing

I present a classroom study, conducted with 13 intermediate-level university students, which tested if corpora helped learners improve L2 writing. Participants were asked to use a corpus to correct their written language errors and later questionnaires and interviews were carried out. Data analysis suggested a decrease in the number of language errors; furthermore, participants believed it
Classroom applications of corpora training for learner autonomy

There is an established belief in ELT that training learners in strategies for independent language analysis fosters a deeper understanding of English. Following up from last year’s research talk on corpora training for increasing learner autonomy, this practical workshop will present three fully-developed activities to use corpora with learners in a classroom environment.
Conceptual interface of corpus-based error analysis through error mapping

This presentation examines the effectiveness of 'error mapping' as a macro and micro error analysis of non-native English language learners' essays. The procedure involved collecting data from essays, interpreting it, reporting information, and implementing it to teaching and learning. Subsequently, students understood their mistakes, identified their needs, learned to avoid mother tongue interference and handed in a competently proofread essay.

There are many language questions that dictionaries, grammar books and native speakers cannot and do not readily answer. The range of questions extends across the whole hierarchy of language from morphology to sentence building to discourse and pragmatics. This talk offers an approach to asking questions to thousands of
native speakers whose language has been sampled and stored in corpora.
Using English Grammar Profile to improve curriculum design
Geraldine Mark (Gloucestershire College/Cambridge University Press) & Anne O'Keeffe (Mary Immaculate College, Limerick/Cambridge University Press)
This talk showcases the English Grammar Profile, a new open educational resource developed to enhance our understanding of English learner grammar.

Based on the Cambridge Learner Corpus, it provides over 1,200 corpus-based grammar competency statements across the six levels of the CEFR. The talk will showcase the resource and explore its importance for the design of materials and curricula.
Focus on B2 writing: preparing students for Cambridge English: First

How can students score top marks? What aspects of writing should they work on at B2? This practical session explores the strengths and weaknesses of candidate performance using real answers from the Cambridge Learner Corpus. Participants will work with the Cambridge English Assessment Scale and evaluate preparation strategies. Learner data from the English Grammar Profile will illustrate useful grammatical development.
Electronic theses online – developing domain-specific corpora from open access
Alannah Fitzgerald (Concordia University) & Chris Mansfield (Queen Mary University of London)

Research findings will be presented from a study into the development and evaluation of domain-specific corpora from the Electronic Theses Online Service (EThOS) at the British Library. These collections were built using the interactive FLAX open-source language software for uptake in English for Specific Academic Purposes (ESAP) programmes at Queen Mary University of London.

Does an explicit focus on grammar help our students? If so, which grammatical structures should we focus on? This talk will argue that form-focused instruction is valuable and that careful selection of structures based on evidence from a corpus is essential in order to plan a targeted syllabus that meets the needs of students preparing for higher education.
Teacher-driven corpus development: the online restaurant review
Chad Langford & Joshua Albair (University Lille 3, France)

We present our project to develop a user-friendly, high-quality corpus of online restaurant reviews, which we consider a specific genre. Our goals are threefold: to present the genesis and results of our project; to elaborate on concrete pedagogical applications (concerning lexis, discourse, grammar and genre-based writing); and to foster collaboration between colleagues eager to develop and share corpora.
Forum on using corpora in the classroom
Guiding EAP learners to autonomously use online corpora: lessons learned

This presentation outlines the lessons learned from an initiative to guide upperintermediate EAP learners to independently use online corpora to improve their written lexical range and accuracy. Experienced and less-experienced educators will leave with a better understanding of the benefits and challenges of training
learners to use corpora, and several online tools and practical resources to use with their learners.
Learning academic vocabulary through a discovery-based approach

This talk will examine the effectiveness of using corpora to learn academic vocabulary. The learning experiences and vocabulary knowledge of two groups of Finnish students will be compared. The findings will show how a discovery-based approach to academic vocabulary acquisition can profitably be embedded in EAP
course design in a Finnish university context.
Exploring EAP teachers' familiarity and experiences of corpora
Rachel Peacock (University of Nottingham Ningbo China)

This talk will present findings of a questionnaire investigating 52 EAP teachers’ understanding and practical classroom experience of corpora. Results highlight that the pedagogical potential of corpus-based applications remains at the research level. To address this, three user-friendly online reference tools that can
be used by students or teachers in various teaching contexts will be introduced.

Tim Johns from the University of Birmingham came up with the term Data Driven Learning (DDL) to describe the different ways language teachers can use corpora and corpus-based evidence in the classroom to support learning. In this workshop, I revisit DDL in order to find out how the methodology can be used with the online resources we currently have available.
Chatting in the academy: exploring spoken English for academic purposes

How does spoken academic English typically differ from academic writing in university settings and how might this influence EAP materials? Using illustrations from corpora, this talk will focus on some key differences to be taken into account when planning materials. Practical examples will be drawn from the
new edition of Academic Vocabulary in Use and from Viewpoint (both CUP).
Error Correction in ESL Writing Using the Learners’ Own Corpora
The presenter discusses using his learners’ corpora to raise their
awareness of the types of errors they make. The ESL corpus consists
of writing collected over two years from his students. The presentation
focuses on the application of corpus analyses to classroom teaching.
John Stasinopoulos, College of DuPage, USA
Longitudinal Learner Corpus: Trends and Uniqueness in Multiword Sequence Use
Knowledge of multiword sequences is deemed a marker of language
proficiency. This session discusses research that explored collective
and unique usages of multiword sequences in a longitudinal learner
corpus. Pedagogical implications to assist in building learners’
repertoire of multiword sequences are provided.
Eman Elturki, Washington State University, USA
Beyond Paragraph and Sentence Borders:Transitioning With Appropriate Linking Adverbials
Making effective and accurate use of transitional language is a
critical skill often missing in L2 students’ writing. In this teaching tip,
the presenter applies corpus-based research to identify key linking
adverbials and demonstrates activities that can be easily integrated
into a variety of ESL composition courses.
Maggie Bullock Oliveira, University of Cincinnati, USA
Enhancing ELLs’ Repertoire of Academic Formulaic Sequences Through Corpora
Learner corpus research has demonstrated that ELLs’ written academic production is largely influenced by spoken register due to the frequency
and salience of spoken-like formulas. In this session, the presenter shares and discusses valuable resources and ideas to enhance students’ repertoire of academic formulas.
Eman Elturki, Washington State University, USA
Engineering Academic Formulas List: Intersecting Corpus Linguistics and Expert Knowledge
Content Area: English for Specific Purposes

As a partial replication of the Academic Formulas List (AFL) project, the study discussed aimed to present a corpus-derived, pedagogically useful list of formulaic sequences for technical engineering writing. Next, this expert formula list was compared with student writing at the novice and advanced levels.
Yaqiong Cui, Michigan State University, USA
Magda Tigchelaar, Michigan State University, USA
Jessica Fox, Michigan State University, USA
Development and Evaluation of a Corpus- Informed Curriculum for International Nurses

This presentation reports on an ESP curriculum for international nurses working in the United States. First, the presenter describes the development of the curriculum, which is based on a corpus-based analysis of 104 nurse-patient interactions. Then, she discusses
evaluation and lessons learned from the first iteration of the course,
If You Build It: A Paradigm for an ESP Corpus Content Area: English for Specific Purposes
The presenter demonstrates how the construction of a corpus of
English for art and design has served as a paradigm for building a
specialty corpus in other disciplines of ESP. Participants learn how to
use corpus tools and then generate language learning activities for
Pamela Vittorio, New School University, USA
Teaching Research Writing With Disciplinary Corpora

In this presentation, the presenters introduce an original cross-disciplinary framework of moves and steps and showcase how such descriptive foundational knowledge was applied to the creation and implementation of pedagogical materials and tasks. Select insights
from students are also expounded, supporting the practical relevance
Stephanie Link, Oklahoma State University, USA
Elena Cotos, Iowa State University, USA
Sarah Huffman, Iowa State University, USA

Hi Emin, if u have not seen them programme & abstracts are available here
The corpora one can access through the BYU interface [
] range from US Soap Operas to British Parliament Speeches, from historical English in the US in the 1800s right up to yesterday’s news on the web in 20 countries round the world.
This allows interested parties a number of ways to look at some language in use.
A recent story about UK politics reports on a politician using the follow language:
No, I just rocked up and then waved at the CCTV.
seems worthy of a little attention. So my thought is
what information can we get about the use of
I’ll post my thoughts in a few weeks. Thanks for any consideration : )

It's great to have such a resource for corpus linguistics. I am amazed though on the non-availability of similar corpora from Twitter. Twitter presents a unique ecosystem that could be researched even for under resourced languages yet the company is making it so difficult to gather content (we are talking for a scenario where the linguist is not programming savvy). In yester years we were able to use desktop applications and sort of copy/paste the content for a particular hashtag or keyword. Nowadays even this is not possible unless you are 24/7 connected and doing this constantly.
BTW, have you used any of the resources from the Clarin network? (
hi Valentini, yes the annoying limitations of using any commercial sources i guess
for Twitter have you tried FireAnt [
i am aware of Clarin though not used any of its resources/tools since i am not a member of any particpating institutions : (
Ah yes so what does BYU-interfaces show us? Rock up when it appears with a pronoun, as in the example "No, I just rocked up.." means to appear or arrive at some place.
I used the following search term -
In COCA there are only two hits with the meaning we are looking for. [
A GLOWBE search is more interesting as it shows a tendency for Australians to use this expression and it tends to appear more in blogs than general websites. [
A search on the NOW corpus shows a couple of hundred occurrences, though not checked if all these have the meaning we are interested in. [
]. Further there seems to have been a peak in use in August 2015. [
]. NOW also shows significant uses in Irish web news.
Although there are only 5 occurrences in CORE, there is a significant use in Travel Blogs.
The handful of hits in COHA do not have the meaning we are interested in. There are no hits in TIME, SOAP, WIKI, CAN or HANSARD corpora.

So our searching suggest that Australians and Irish use this and the contexts of use are informal. This could fit in with the campaign strategy of the politician who used this phrase, i.e. to appear likeable and "normal".

message: over at the FB tleap site asks the following questions:
* Do you actively include corpora somehow? What's a good activity?
* Which corpora are germane to the courses we teach?
* What are your apprehensions of using corpora? Are there considerations to be aware of?
* How do you keep it from taking over your life? <--eh? : )
tleap (focused on EAP issues) is a closed group  so you need to be a FB user to join; reposting Tyson's questions here for us FB haters : )

Tyson's first question I think may, to me anyway, assume that one needs to find a way to use a tool such as corpora outside any other considerations. I am sure this is not what Tyson intended. I make this point due to my own initial enthusiasm for corpora that sometimes led me astray from communicative needs. I think with any tool one discovers, the initial exploration does tend to blind you, well me anyway for sure.
As I often point out here the text by Ana FrankenBerg-Garcia is an excellent reminder to integrate corpora as needed in class. [
Already commenters in the tleap thread have pointed out many excellent corpora that are appropriate for EAP contexts (MICUSP, MICASE, BAWE). I'll add here a link to a
This might be a good opportunity to get others to contribute so here is a Google Form to enter your ideas of corpora suitable for Academic English [
Having said this one way to make corpora ideas less intimidating to students is to use Google as a corpus/concordancer; I describe a little how, over at HLT Magazine - [
As to the last question let...me...check...a...cor.... oh yes no erm...
G+ hater here: Thanks for the repost and answers Mura. :)

Fiction genre and learner collocational knowledge

Fiction genre in both COCA and BNC best predicts (i.e. highest correlation with) learner collocation knowledge, Durrant (2014). This could be useful to select collocations to use with lower proficiency students. For higher proficiency students filter the previous list by mutual information (MI) score in COCA as learners are known to be weak with low (word) frequency items that MI scores pick out. Or use the KWIC function of COCA to easily see any idiomatic uses that higher proficiency learners may want to learn.
For example searching on collocations of all uses of
in the Fiction section in COCA shows highly frequent collocations include
. These can be appropriate for low proficiency learners.
Filtering by MI score we have contraction of
. Looking more closely in a KWIC search in COCA we see uses of the idiom
. These may be appropriate for higher proficiency students to learn.
Durrant, P. (2014). Corpus frequency and second language learners’ knowledge of collocations: A meta-analysis. International Journal of Corpus Linguistics, 19, 443–477.

Hi Mura, thanks for starting this community. I was checking out the link you posted on Leo Selivan blogpost (usage-based by Ellis) and hit me that what I have been doing with my 9th graders will at some point be questioned because in a more traditional view of teaching which is based in grammar or topic based to support grammar presentation. What I just thought of doing today was to keep track myself and find a way to catalogue of the videos we use in class - more like uncovering the language and dealing with the emergence of it as learners are provoked to give their opinions, share stories and respond to questions. Is there a tool which I could use to catalogue the occurences in class ( audiovisual material especially) and in students production work? Thus creating our own corpus. I hope I am making any sense. It seems that this would help me in a number of ways this bimester. What do you think?
hi Rose, great to see you here :), i did not see such a community so why not make one! am hoping there is a lot of interest out there.
do you want to capture the language your students use in class? from video/audio that you have recorded?
you could also look at the work done on the BACKBONE corpus
and the annotation systems used in that?

your project would be of great interest to this group for sure, i'd be happy to help out in transcribing and such (e.g. learning to use a system like EXMARaLDA, if it applies to what u have in mind), let me know.

Exactly what I have in mind. Thanks for the suggestions. I'm going to check the links and I'll get back to you soon. One of the outcomes of recording classes was that I started noticing that higer levels were still using the same vocabulary choices than lower levels when talking about for instance what they did last week. That led me to pay more attention to lexical and learning process of vocabulary. 1) they focus on grammar and almost dimiss vocabulary which I find weird as what they do in practice is the opposite. They talk about their weekend using for example, simple present instead totally forgetting about the ED ending or the irregular form.  2) higher level can say more words, but don't incorporate collocations, they actually still doing the translation process. I thought these observation I made with my various groups led me to rethink what I was doing and I'm trying to switch the process. I know though that is a tall order as most of them have been doing like this for over 3 years already. I hope that by pointing out chunks more explicity that they will start producing chunks more naturally. So capturing what they produce in class I think it will be absolutely essential to help them notice and assess their learning. It has been a learning curve this year for me as a teacher.
that is a great question to explore - how would watching or listening to yourself producing english affect your subsequent use?
certainly in other fields like sport - watching and analysing  your own performance is widespread.
i have read an account of students transcribing their own conversations -and using this as a way to feedback into future conversations. e.g.
look forward to development on this :)
Thanks Mura. I'm excited to see how it develops myself.
Thanks again for the tools you shared and for the article. I'm looking into the exmaralda right now. Learning how to use it.
Thank you for inviting me. I'm looking forward to learning a lot here!
hello Monika, thanks so much for joining and welcome to everyone else as well.

though maybe a "classroom experience with corpora" section would be more appropriate?
balancing the number of sections is tricky; maybe the two i.e. discussion and reading are enough?

AntConc is freeware software which lets you perform KWIC searches, do concordances and produce keyword lists.
It's a useful light program which language students can use to help see how words are used. It's not a full-on concordancer but for casual use it's brilliant.

hi Noor I would point your teachers to say a text like Integrating corpora with everyday language teaching [

So even classes with limited computers can get to use corpora if it is useful in that particular context.
Aside from that caveat then tell them to read this community ;)

We hope you find this interesting

A linguistic philosopher called Jerry Fodor conceived a fascinating idea - that we are all born with the ability to speak a language. The language is inside our brains from our first moment. It's not the English language, or any other natural language. It's the language of thought. Other philosophers disagree. Just as not everyone agrees with Chomsky's Universal Grammar. But it's a fascinating idea. What do you think? Is Fodor guilty of an 'infinite regress' with his argument?

What code to use to remove all quoted texts from a corpus / or a long single text?
Anyone knows any line of code in any programming language that helps to omit quoted texts marked by quotations marks from a long text or a corpus of long texts? Will be really grateful for the help!﻿
hi the most obvious is to use regular expressions e.g.
or you can do this with a text editor that does regex e.g. Notepadd++

Thanks a lot for your comment; I'll give it a go. I'm trying to delete all quoted texts from a written learner corpus I collected as the quoted texts are not theirs, so the analysis results will be skewed!!
do post back here with any findings : )
Keep a copy of your original corpus. You might want to do some research on what was quoted, perhaps who knows?, and it would definitely be useful. :)
yes I do keep a copy of the original file. I have to convert the copied files to .txt as input for Python so cannot use the original .doc texts; but thanks for the comment
, if you have the corpus as DOC then all you have to do is save it in .txt using Notepad++ (as

mentioned) and don't forget about encoding (in case you are dealing with languages like Greek that requires Unicode). If you keep the original DOCs though you still have your corpus ;) ... I think that the conversion of your raw texts (DOCs) into TXT without altering will take only a few moments. You can even use the Zilla batch converter to make your life even easier:

That's right Valentini, another way is to click 'save as' in Word, choose Text Encoded, choose UTF-8 (for Linux), choose CR/LF  for End line with, click ok and gives you a plain .txt format; hope this comes handy for others some times!
update: Pete Bleackley gave me a line of code in Python that might come handy for others as well:
Thanks to Pete for his prompt response!

Out of curiosity. Have you normalized your documents? i.e. are you sure that all quoted text uses indeed the quotation marks and that the mark is always the same? I am asking because, for example, block quotations do not need the quotation marks. Do you, perhaps, also have quotes within quotes?

Also, is your corpus in Us English or UK English? UK uses single quotes for quotations and double quotes for the quote within a quote scenario, while US English uses the exact opposite. The regex provided by Mr. Bleackley doesn't include the single quotes also...
Sorry if I am being a pest but the issue of quotation marks is a bit more complex than we usually think.
